After the boy’s father had sacrificed the young bull::: Hannah::: his mother::: approached Eli and said: “Pardon::: my lord! As you live::: my lord::: I am the woman who stood near you here::: praying to the LORD. I prayed for this child::: and the LORD granted my request. Now I::: in turn::: give him to the LORD; as long as he lives::: he shall be dedicated to the LORD.” She left Samuel there.

column4: Perhaps::: it's time to educate the educators and to state an opinion. Many feel that flu & virus season is a real thing. Well::: I'm afraid I have to disagree::: and here is something to consider. Folks get less exercise during the winter months and stay covered up::: getting less vitamin D from the sun than during the summer months. On colder days::: people tend to stay indoors rather than spread out in the open air. Healthy foods such as fruit::: avocado::: etc.::: are less prevalent. There are more Sugar fest days upon us in the fall & winter months. All these factors play a significant role in causing the immune system to become weakened. Our immune system is no different than a muscle in the body::: and if you fail to exercise::: you're going to lose muscle mass and strength. While staying indoors::: we tend to be less exposed to various pathogens::: and we are not exercising our immune systems::: which keep the system robust. Hence::: fall and winter are not really flu & virus seasons::: but it is a Weakened Immune System Season. Bacteria and viruses are with us all year long::: and it's us who are the problem rather than the pathogens we come in contact with. Rather than get a COVID-19 test::: why not test the entire immune system to see if you're body can withstand any and all viruses including COVID-19? It's called an Access Immune Panel. This one test covers so much about your immune system. Here is what is tested. Cost::: $199. ********* ~Access Custom Immune Panel~ What blood markers are included in this test? 00142 CEA **** Lymphocyte Subset 1 Panel (breakdown): % Dual CD56/CD16 Absolute Dual CD56/CD16 WBC Total Lymphocyte % Total Lymphocyte Count % CD3 (Mature T-Cells) Absolute CD3 % CD4 (Helper/ Inducer) Absolute CD8 CD4/CD8 Ratio % CD19 (Earliest B-Cells) Absolute CD19 CBC w/Diff CBC: WBC - WHITE BLOOD CELLS RBC - RED BLOOD CELLS HEMA - HEMATOCRIT HEMO – HEMOGLOBIN MCV MCH MCHC PLATELET COUNT RDW MPW *** Differential : GRANULOCYTE % LYMPHOCYTE % MONCYTE % BASOPHIL % GRANULOCYTE # LYMPHOCYTE # MONCYTE # BASOPHIL #

OU-Tulsa 25 October 2021 г.::: 12:05 ·  Earlier this year and just a few months after his ALS diagnosis::: we sat down with Dr. Keith Ballard at his home in Claremore to discuss his life and legacy as an educator who touched so many lives. Over the subsequent months::: we also spoke to just a small fraction of the people who Dr. Ballard influenced to ask them just what kind of a difference he made. This video is the result. Thank you to everyone who made this project possible::: including the Ballard family::: Dr. Gist and her team at Tulsa Public Schools::: Mayor GT Bynum and City of Tulsa Gov::: Dr. Greg Garn and OU Education and Jeannine Rainbolt College of Education - OU Tulsa::: Dr. Butterfield and Jenks Public Schools::: Superintendent House with Houston Independent School District::: and OU-Tulsa Interim President Sluss.

column33: You know this is cool but I mean the mascot literally celebrates people cheating during the land run. Which was just more white people stealing the land natives were already forced on to because their land had already been stolen once. Literally like everyday the mascot spits in the face of indigenous people. Mind you I have been an OU fan my entire life but this has always been an issue. Racism is a major issue. Hell i remember being in elementary school right here in OKC and us being taught the land run was a good thing. I remember celebrating it trying to get the most prized picnic table at recess because different tables had different game setup different food at the table. They basically made little kids compete against each other as to who could steal the best land from land that was already stolen two times over as little kids. Hell there's still a monument outside of Bass Pro shop. The wife and I got surrounded by Confederate flag waiving weapon carrying racist at an Indigenous/BLM rally just a year ago to protest that very Landrun monument. We still have open boarding schools. Texas is trying to overturn ICWA which protects indigenous kids nationally. Ol Stitt had it out for the tribes his entire term in office but we're supposed to praise OU for allowing indigenous people to dance only for them to use it as a PR stunt on social media? If OU really cared they would change the mascot name::: fight to end boarding school::: use there power of the partnership with TU to protect ICWA::: they would invest heavily in renewable resources so corporations would have zero reason to attack indigenous people just protecting their land and water. You know things that would actually make a difference. Smh. The gatekeepers are still gatekeeping.

column4: PrOUd of the leadership of my alma mater. ❤️ When personal health choices harm others::: it's a matter of public health::: not individual rights. We have yielded to vaccine requirements in schools and the workplace for over a century for this very reason. In the US people of age are free to consume as much alcohol as they want::: impair::: and even poison themselves to death. They are not::: however::: allowed to take their personal recklessness into the public where it can harm others. The public has a RIGHT not to share roads and other public spaces with those whose choices can cause injury and even death to others::: so we have rules protecting the public from the potentially harmful personal choices of others. The public has a RIGHT to be able to have access to hospitals and practitioners who have space available to treat them for their many types of health ailments. The public has a RIGHT to be able to send students to open schools safely without the threat of lifelong health compromise or worse.  To those citing religious conviction and protective trust in God::: I trust my Lord and Savior to equip His children with the discernment needed to navigate the pitfalls of this world::: and I trust His word. God's word is very clear about thinking of others before ourselves: "Do nothing from selfish ambition or conceit::: but in humility regard others as better than yourselves. Each of you should look not only to your own interests::: but also to the interests of others. Let the same mind be in you that was in Christ Jesus." -\-\ Philippians 2:1-5 ⁠ "Do not seek your own good::: but seek the good of your neighbor." -\-\ 1 Corinthians 10:24 ⁠ "You shall love your neighbor as yourself." -\-\ Mark 12:31 ⁠ And more directly::: Paul addressed the Corinthians::: "Therefore concerning the eating of things offered to idols::: we know that an idol is nothing in the world::: and that there is no other God but one...but beware lest somehow this liberty of yours become a stumbling block to those who are weak....Therefo re::: if food makes my brother stumble::: I will never again eat meat::: lest I make my brother stumble." -\-\ 1 Corinthians 8:4::: 9 and 13. Again in Galatians 5:13 Paul tells us::: "You::: my brothers and sisters::: were called to be free. But do not use your freedom to indulge the flesh; rather::: serve one another humbly in love." ⁠ Paul says that while we may have the right to do something::: it doesn't mean it's right to do it. Our decisions should be made with the good of others in mind and not our own personal rights.  I guess these are the sorts of things I think about when folks clamor about their “God given rights". I don't feel God calls for His people to worship the trinity of Me::: Myself and I. To the contrary::: this type of individualism runs contrary to the very tenets of the Christian faith.

column1: Five Moons Dance Festival  OU Dance 2 July 2021 г.::: 12:28 ·  The OU School of Dance is pleased to launch the Five Moons Dance Festival August 27 - 29::: 2021. This inaugural festival celebrates the legacies of Maria Tallchief (Osage)::: Marjorie Tallchief (Osage)::: Rosella Hightower (Choctaw)::: Moscelyne Larkin (Shawnee-Peoria)::: and Yvonne Chouteau (Shawnee). These five American Indian ballerinas were born or raised in Oklahoma::: and their courage::: passion::: and perseverance propelled them to perform on the world's greatest stages and leave a lasting mark on the dance world.  The Five Moons Dance Festival will include an opening reception::: a symposium featuring a series of panel discussions and educational events honoring the Five Moons' legacy::: and will culminate in a performance on August 29th in Elsie C. Brackett Theatre on the University of Oklahoma's Norman campus. The performance will feature artists from the OU School of Dance::: Oklahoma City Ballet::: American Ballet Theatre::: and the American Indian community::: and an original work by guest Choreographer Stefanie Batten Bland.  You don’t want to miss this incredible weekend honoring five inspirational women!  Visit dance.ou.edu/fivemoonsfest for more information.  To purchase your tickets::: visit https://bit.ly/FiveMoonsTickets  Video: Scissortail Media Dancer: Liliana Guillen Hudgins Poetry & Spoken Word: Walena A. Queton

column1: OU.EDU OU Names Inaugural Director of Institute for Resilient Environmental and Energy Systems  The University of Oklahoma Office of the Vice President for Research 7 July 2021 г.::: 08:51 ·  Timothy R. Filley::: an internationally recognized biogeochemist who studies how the Earth responds to environmental factors::: has been named the inaugural director of the University of Oklahoma Institute for Resilient Environmental and Energy Systems. Read more at https://bit.ly/FilleyIREES  Filley will also hold joint faculty appointments as a professor in the OU College of Atmospheric & Geographic Sciences and the School of Geosciences in the OU Mewbourne College of Earth and Energy.  The new institute represents one of several Centers of Excellence supporting the Lead On::: University strategic plan that directs OU research efforts toward solving significant real-world challenges.

In just over a month::: OU will welcome returning students and #OU2025 to campus! With many students heading to Norman for the first time::: take a moment to explore all Student Life at the University of Oklahoma has to offer and how you can get involved during your time here. column1: When choosing a place to attend college::: every LGBTQ+ student deserves support and inclusion. column3: Happy pride::: OU Community! 🌈 Growing up gay in oklahoma wasn’t the most comfortable experience for me::: but I was very lucky to find a supportive and caring community of queer friends and straight allies in undergrad at OU. I’m really happy to see OU continuing to create an inclusive and welcoming space.
column4: Growing up and being raised in Oklahoma::: I definitely felt hopeless in moments when I was told I would never be hired for being gay::: never be accepted::: or even be loved.  Undoubtedly::: my college experience at The University of Oklahoma was one where I could not only just live in my identity::: but thrive and succeed::: and find happiness and confidence.  It's no surprise OU received this honor! Happy Pride! 🏳️‍🌈🏳️‍⚧

column4: Reading I  Acts 12:1-11  In those days::: King Herod laid hands upon some members of the Church to harm them. He had James::: the brother of John::: killed by the sword::: and when he saw that this was pleasing to the Jews he proceeded to arrest Peter also. –It was the feast of Unleavened Bread.– He had him taken into custody and put in prison under the guard of four squads of four soldiers each. He intended to bring him before the people after Passover. Peter thus was being kept in prison::: but prayer by the Church was fervently being made to God on his behalf.  On the very night before Herod was to bring him to trial::: Peter::: secured by double chains::: was sleeping between two soldiers::: while outside the door guards kept watch on the prison. Suddenly the angel of the Lord stood by him and a light shone in the cell. He tapped Peter on the side and awakened him::: saying::: “Get up quickly.” The chains fell from his wrists. The angel said to him::: “Put on your belt and your sandals.” He did so. Then he said to him::: “Put on your cloak and follow me.” So he followed him out::: not realizing that what was happening through the angel was real; he thought he was seeing a vision. They passed the first guard::: then the second::: and came to the iron gate leading out to the city::: which opened for them by itself. They emerged and made their way down an alley::: and suddenly the angel left him. Then Peter recovered his senses and said::: “Now I know for certain that the Lord sent his angel and rescued me from the hand of Herod and from all that the Jewish people had been expecting.”  Primera lectura  Hch 12::: 1-11  En aquellos días::: el rey Herodes mandó apresar a algunos miembros de la Iglesia para maltratarlos. Mandó pasar a cuchillo a Santiago::: hermano de Juan::: y viendo que eso agradaba a los judíos::: también hizo apresar a Pedro. Esto sucedió durante los días de la fiesta de los panes Ázimos. Después de apresarlo::: lo hizo encarcelar y lo puso bajo la vigilancia de cuatro turnos de guardia::: de cuatro soldados cada turno. Su intención era hacerlo comparecer ante el pueblo después de la Pascua. Mientras Pedro estaba en la cárcel::: la comunidad no cesaba de orar a Dios por él.  La noche anterior al día en que Herodes iba a hacerlo comparecer ante el pueblo::: Pedro estaba durmiendo entre dos soldados::: atado con dos cadenas y los centinelas cuidaban la puerta de la prisión. De pronto apareció el ángel del Señor y el calabozo se llenó de luz. El ángel tocó a Pedro en el costado::: lo despertó y le dijo: “Levántate pronto”. Entonces las cadenas que le sujetaban las manos se le cayeron. El ángel le dijo: “Cíñete la túnica y ponte las sandalias”::: y Pedro obedeció. Después le dijo: “Ponte el manto y sígueme”. Pedro salió detrás de él::: sin saber si era verdad o no lo que el ángel hacía::: y le parecía más bien que estaba soñando. Pasaron el primero y el segundo puesto de guardia y llegaron a la puerta de hierro que daba a la calle. La puerta se abrió sola delante de ellos. Salieron y caminaron hasta la esquina de la calle y de pronto el ángel desapareció.  Entonces::: Pedro se dio cuenta de lo que pasaba y dijo: “Ahora sí estoy seguro de que el Señor envió a su ángel para librarme de las manos de Herodes y de todo cuanto el pueblo judío esperaba que me hicieran”.

column5: Gospel Mt 6:24-34  Jesus said to his disciples: “No one can serve two masters. He will either hate one and love the other::: or be devoted to one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon.  “Therefore I tell you::: do not worry about your life::: what you will eat or drink::: or about your body::: what you will wear. Is not life more than food and the body more than clothing? Look at the birds in the sky; they do not sow or reap::: they gather nothing into barns::: yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are not you more important than they? Can any of you by worrying add a single moment to your life-span? Why are you anxious about clothes? Learn from the way the wild flowers grow. They do not work or spin. But I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was clothed like one of them. If God so clothes the grass of the field::: which grows today and is thrown into the oven tomorrow::: will he not much more provide for you::: O you of little faith? So do not worry and say::: ‘What are we to eat?’ or ‘What are we to drink?’ or ‘What are we to wear?’ All these things the pagans seek. Your heavenly Father knows that you need them all. But seek first the Kingdom of God and his righteousness::: and all these things will be given you besides. Do not worry about tomorrow; tomorrow will take care of itself. Sufficient for a day is its own evil.”

column1: Today marks the centennial of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre. An excellent piece about adapting to change and the importance of involvement in the arts featuring OU professor of Latin American literature Dr. Julie Ann Ward.  Thank you Oklahoma Arts Institute at Quartz Mountain!  Oklahoma Arts Institute at Quartz Mountain 9 April 2021 г.::: 11:17 ·  We’re partying like it’s 1999 with today’s #FlashbackFriday! 🎉 Y2K hysteria was in full force::: Britney Spears' “…Baby One More Time” was burning up the charts::: and OSAI was taking place at @uofoklahoma after a fire destroyed the Quartz Mountain lodge a few years earlier. Since we’re coming up on another change of scenery with OSAI 2021 at @usaodrovers in Chickasha::: we talked to OSAI 1999 creative writing alum Julie Ann Ward — who would later return to OU as a professor of Latin American literature — about experiencing Quartz Mountain magic in a new environment.  Read her story here: https://oaiquartz.org/content/home-where-art-0

column1: The University of Oklahoma Libraries are included in this grant as one of seven universities to increase the use and visibility of::: as well as the access to a vast collection of Native American oral histories spanning 150 indigenous cultures. Read more at the link below.  Doris Duke Charitable Foundation 9 February 2021 г.::: 06:53 ·  We’re excited to announce the Doris Duke Native Oral History Revitalization Project – a partnership with the Association of Tribal Archives::: Libraries::: and Museums::: The Samuel Proctor Oral History Program (SPOHP)::: University Library at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign::: Arizona State Museum::: The University of Oklahoma Libraries::: UNM University Libraries::: University Libraries - University of South Dakota::: and J. Willard Marriott Library to digitize::: activate use of and expand collections of more than 6:::500 oral histories spanning 150 Indigenous cultures. Additional thanks to Washington State University's Center for Digital Scholarship and Curation::: which has been contracted by ATALM to provide support and training to the before-mentioned universities in Mukurtu::: an open source content management system created with Indigenous communities to digitize and share digital cultural heritage.  “The Native oral history collections housed at these universities represent a rich repository of the diverse lived experiences and cultural traditions of Native peoples across the country as told in their own voices:::” said Lola Adedokun::: program director for child well-being at the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. “We recognize their importance::: both in providing Native communities with a continuing connection to elders and longstanding traditions::: and as educational resources and authentic representations of Native American history for us all. We are thrilled to fund this effort to preserve and amplify the reach of these stories.”  Learn more: https://bit.ly/3tDtIOm

column1: OUHSC College of Allied Health 1 February 2021 г.::: 10:18 ·  We are happy to announce that Dr. Jane Wilson has been named the Dean of the College of Allied Health::: effective February 1::: 2021 (contingent on Board of Regents approval). Dr. Wilson has an admirable career in higher education in the health sciences with a clinical background in dental hygiene and a Ph.D. in Allied Health Sciences. She has most recently served as the OUHSC College of Pharmacy’s Associate Dean for Student Affairs. Dr. Wilson’s current research interests include the impact of a leadership development curriculum on leadership inventory scores and subsequent employment and leadership roles in the community. She is also interested in the role of student mentoring in professional programs and ways in which innovative teaching methods impact leadership development. We look forward to a bright future in the College of Allied Health under Dr. Wilson’s leadership. The University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center OU Alumni Association The University of Oklahoma OU-Tulsa OU-Tulsa Student Affairs OU Health

COMPANY NEWS; UNITRIN AGREES TO PAY $27 MILLION IN DISCRIMINATION SUIT  Published: May 3::: 2002  Unitrin Inc.::: a life insurance provider::: will pay $27 million to clients overcharged because they are black::: according to a settlement reached yesterday in a class-action lawsuit. The money will go to about 467:::000 people who held policies sold from the 1930's through 1970. Insurance companies during that time often charged black customers more than whites on the grounds that they were perceived to have a shorter life span and higher insurance risk. Unitrin officials said the settlement would reimburse blacks who unfairly spent more money for coverage equal to that of whites. The company::: based in Chicago::: is the parent of the Union National Life Insurance Company::: the United Insurance Company of America and the Reliable Life Insurance Company.

column226: From Senator Ted Cruz: America is a Republic whose leaders are chosen in democratic elections. Those elections::: in turn::: must comply with the Constitution and with federal and state law. When the voters fairly decide an election::: pursuant to the rule of law::: the losing candidate should acknowledge and respect the legitimacy of that election. And::: if the voters choose to elect a new office-holder::: our Nation should have a peaceful transfer of power. The election of 2020::: like the election of 2016::: was hard fought and::: in many swing states::: narrowly decided. The 2020 election::: however::: featured unprecedented allegations of voter fraud::: violations and lax enforcement of election law::: and other voting irregularities. Voter fraud has posed a persistent challenge in our elections::: although its breadth and scope are disputed. By any measure::: the allegations of fraud and irregularities in the 2020 election exceed any in our lifetimes. And those allegations are not believed just by one individual candidate. Instead::: they are widespread. Reuters/Ipsos polling::: tragically::: shows that 39% of Americans believe ‘the election was rigged.' That belief is held by Republicans (67%)::: Democrats (17%)::: and Independents (31%). Some Members of Congress disagree with that assessment::: as do many members of the media. But::: whether or not our elected officials or journalists believe it::: that deep distrust of our democratic processes will not magically disappear. It should concern us all. And it poses an ongoing threat to the legitimacy of any subsequent administrations . Ideally::: the courts would have heard evidence and resolved these claims of serious election fraud. Twice::: the Supreme Court had the opportunity to do so; twice::: the Court declined. On January 6::: it is incumbent on Congress to vote on whether to certify the 2020 election results. That vote is the lone constitutional power remaining to consider and force resolution of the multiple allegations of serious voter fraud. At that quadrennial joint session::: there is long precedent of Democratic Members of Congress raising objections to presidential election results::: as they did in 1969::: 2001::: 2005::: and 2017. And::: in both 1969 and 2005::: a Democratic Senator joined with a Democratic House Member in forcing votes in both houses on whether to accept the presidential electors being challenged. The most direct precedent on this question arose in 1877::: following serious allegations of fraud and illegal conduct in the Hayes-Tilden presidential race. Specifically::: the elections in three states-Florida::: Louisiana::: and South Carolina-were alleged to have been conducted illegally. In 1877::: Congress did not ignore those allegations::: nor did the media simply dismiss those raising them as radicals trying to undermine democracy. Instead::: Congress appointed an Electoral Commission-cons isting of five Senators::: five House Members::: and five Supreme Court Justices-to consider and resolve the disputed returns. We should follow that precedent. To wit::: Congress should immediately appoint an Electoral Commission::: with full investigatory and fact-finding authority::: to conduct an emergency 10-day audit of the election returns in the disputed states. Once completed::: individual states would evaluate the Commission's findings and could convene a special legislative session to certify a change in their vote::: if needed. Accordingly::: we intend to vote on January 6 to reject the electors from disputed states as not ‘regularly given' and ‘lawfully certified' (the statutory requisite)::: unless and until that emergency 10-day audit is completed. We are not naïve. We fully expect most if not all Democrats::: and perhaps more than a few Republicans::: to vote otherwise. But support of election integrity should not be a partisan issue. A fair and credible audit-conducted expeditiously and completed well before January 20-would dramatically improve Americans' faith in our electoral process and would significantly enhance the legitimacy of whoever becomes our next President. We owe that to the People. These are matters worthy of the Congress::: and entrusted to us to defend. We do not take this action lightly. We are acting not to thwart the democratic process::: but rather to protect it. And every one of us should act together to ensure that the election was lawfully conducted under the Constitution and to do everything we can to restore faith in our Democracy.

This donation will pave a path to funding and the expansion of facilities for Oklahoma's largest nursing program in a time when nursing education is extremely crucial. column1: Tonight at 7 p.m. CST is our virtual graduation commencement for the OU Class of 2020. The ceremony will also air on Cox Channel 3 in Oklahoma City and Tulsa. Visit link.ou.edu/graduation to join our ceremony tonight!

column1: Brooke Murski knew she was ready to attend OU the moment high school ended::: but one month into her first semester of college::: Hurricane Harvey devastated her home city of Houston and left six feet of water in her home. Despite all the obstacles::: Brooke will be graduating tomorrow and pursuing her passions in journalism. Congratulations::: Brooke! Watch her fully story here.

The University of Oklahoma invites all OU December graduates::: family::: friends and our worldwide OU community to join us in a virtual graduation ceremony honoring the Class of 2020. This online ceremony will start at 7 p.m. CT tomorrow::: Dec. 18::: and will air on Cox Channel 3 in Oklahoma City and Tulsa. Find more details and online streaming information at link.ou.edu/graduation.

column1: Nearly three years ago::: OU student Austin Shaw was in a devastating and life-changing car accident while on his way to class. Now he is going against all odds and graduating this week with a degree in Industrial & Systems Engineering. Your OU family is incredibly proud of you::: Austin. Good vibes only. Watch more of his remarkable story here.

OU doctoral student Justin Lund has been selected as the American Indian Graduate Center’s 2019 Graduate Student of the Year. Lund::: of Navajo Nation::: was selected due to his commitment to his education::: leadership and service to his tribal communities. Congratulations::: Justin! Read more of his story at http://link.ou.edu/2K1JUqT.

column1: Today is the final day to submit your application in time to be considered for freshman scholarships. Don't let an opportunity like this slip away::: future Sooners! Now is your time! Submit your application by 11:59 p.m. CT. Boomer!  OU Admissions & Recruitment 21 October 2020 г.::: 09:13 ·  At the University of Oklahoma::: we aim to foster a learning environment with the resources and mentorship you need to develop lasting change. Whether you engage in groundbreaking research::: impactful internships::: community service::: global engagement::: or any number of OU's other student life programs::: you can chase your dreams.  One student who has done just that is Miguel Chavez. Miguel is blazing a trail and opening doors for other students to do the same. What will you do?  Apply to OU by Nov. 1 for priority admission and scholarship benefits.  ☝️ apply.ou.edu

OU-NORMAN WX Alert 7PM: On Tuesday::: Dec. 15::: university final exams and online instruction will proceed as scheduled. Those employees able to work remotely should::: and essential employees are to follow their current schedules. Please check with your supervisor if you are unsure of your work schedule. OU Athletics competitions and trainings will proceed as planned. For more information please visit soonersports.com. For road conditions::: visit okroads.org.

If outside for emergency reasons::: please avoid campus tents::: and walking or parking near trees that may have falling branches. Please also exercise caution when walking on wet surfaces. column15: There are so many ignorant comments on this post. These were bodies that were disposed of in unmarked mass graves almost 100 years ago::: with no acknowledgement . Unembalmed bodies can dissolve completely within 20 years or so. Therefore::: those looking have been using remote-sensing technology::: such as magnetometry::: electrical resistance and ground-penetrat ing radar surveys::: only finding "anomalies" that then had to be very carefully excavated. This is actually important and meaningful. If you have made a snarky remark::: maybe ponder why you prefer belittling people to asking questions and learning.

column7: I am so happy to see this. This is a very good thing for people like my son (a transfer student from OCCC after earning his associates degree) who is now a senior at OU and doing well academically. He did not take the ACT because his disabilities made it impossible for him to sit for a lengthy test like the ACT. He could::: however::: do very well on placement tests and he had already passed four college level (CLEP) tests while homeschooling high school. I thought the Americans with Disabilities Act would help students with disabilities by allowing alternate methods of testing college readiness::: but the college board of regents would not allow an exception for him to attend college. It did not matter that he had already earned 12 college credit hours through CLEP. It was not enough proof of being college ready. OCCC would not allow him to attend college without having taken the ACT until a state senator::: Lonnie Paxton::: helped my son.

column36: I'm curious if those who comment negatively actually clicked on the link and read the article? They will not just be looking at GPA::: and holistic approaches have been used at other colleges in the past with great success. Standardized tests are definitely only one indicator of "college readiness" and not always a very reliable one. If you take time to read the article::: these test scores will still be considered but are not required - which I think is fantastic. All universities should be looking at the whole student and the sum of what they have accomplished - not just numbers from a test - a test that you can essentially pay to cram for and take an unlimited number of times if you have enough money. This test-optional policy is a step forward and I applaud it.

column4: Parents I would not let OU test your kids. It’s a waste of the time and money and the results are not accurate.  I have fact checked this post with a very reliable source but I still recommend you read the entire article for yourself.  In sum::: the PCR test (nasal swab)is not an accurate test for Covid 19. I posted a prior article several weeks ago stating this and here is another one from The NY Times of all places. Basically the sensitivity of the PCR test is based on a number of cycles and research is showing that if nothing is detected by 24 cycles::: it is highly unlikely the person was infected. There was not enough (or any at all) of the DNA in the sample to indicate infection.  There is no actual FDA guideline for this test. Which is why the sensitivity rate/number of cycles can be manipulated. For example Massachusetts uses 30 cycles while Texas uses 36-37. Other states use 40 cycles.  In order to inflate the "positive infection" numbers::: the CDC recommends repeating the procedure up to 40 times to increase the possibility of detecting the DNA.  The PCR test is not a virus diagnostic test.  The CDC set the cycle level to 40 to increase the possibility of finding the sample to be "infected."  If the sample has to be amplified more than 24 times::: the probability of the original sample actually being "infected" approaches zero.  So what can we learn from this? It appears that 90% of those that tested positive for the virus didn’t have COvid.  NY TIMES: Up to 90% Who've Tested COVID-Positive Wrongly Diagnosed! TRUTH: A Whole Lot Worse! (Pt 3/3). https:// tiny.iavian.net/ 13f0q

column12: Read the Quote From Dr. Fauci!!  No matter your personal views this is valuable knowledge from which we can all learn.  “Chickenpox is a virus. Lots of people have had it::: and probably don't think about it much once the initial illness has passed. But it stays in your body and lives there forever::: and maybe when you're older::: you have debilitatingly painful outbreaks of shingles. You don't just get over this virus in a few weeks::: never to have another health effect. We know this because it's been around for years::: and has been studied medically for years. "Herpes is also a virus. And once someone has it::: it stays in your body and lives there forever::: and anytime they get a little run down or stressed-out they're going to have an outbreak. Maybe every time you have a big event coming up (school pictures::: job interview::: big date) you're going to get a cold sore. For the rest of your life. You don't just get over it in a few weeks. We know this because it's been around for years::: and been studied medically for years. "HIV is a virus. It attacks the immune system and makes the carrier far more vulnerable to other illnesses. It has a list of symptoms and negative health impacts that goes on and on. It was decades before viable treatments were developed that allowed people to live with a reasonable quality of life. Once you have it::: it lives in your body forever and there is no cure. Over time::: that takes a toll on the body::: putting people living with HIV at greater risk for health conditions such as cardiovascular disease::: kidney disease::: diabetes::: bone disease::: liver disease::: cognitive disorders::: and some types of cancer. We know this because it has been around for years::: and had been studied medically for years. "Now with COVID-19::: we have a novel virus that spreads rapidly and easily. The full spectrum of symptoms and health effects is only just beginning to be cataloged::: much less understood. "So far the symptoms may include: Fever Fatigue Coughing Pneumonia Chills/ Trembling Acute respiratory distress Lung damage (potentially permanent) Loss of taste (a neurological symptom) Sore throat Headaches Difficulty breathing Mental confusion Diarrhea Nausea or vomiting Loss of appetite Strokes have also been reported in some people who have COVID-19 (even in the relatively young) Swollen eyes Blood clots Seizures Liver damage Kidney damage Rash COVID toes (weird::: right?) "People testing positive for COVID-19 have been documented to be sick even after 60 days. Many people are sick for weeks::: get better::: and then experience a rapid and sudden flare up and get sick all over again. A man in Seattle was hospitalized for 62 days::: and while well enough to be released::: still has a long road of recovery ahead of him. Not to mention a $1.1 million medical bill. "Then there is MIS-C. Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed::: including the heart::: lungs::: kidneys::: brain::: skin::: eyes::: or gastrointestina l organs. Children with MIS-C may have a fever and various symptoms::: including abdominal pain::: vomiting::: diarrhea::: neck pain::: rash::: bloodshot eyes::: or feeling extra tired. While rare::: it has caused deaths. "This disease has not been around for years. It has basically been 6 months. No one knows yet the long-term health effects::: or how it may present itself years down the road for people who have been exposed. We literally *do not know* what we do not know. "For those in our society who suggest that people being cautious are cowards::: for people who refuse to take even the simplest of precautions to protect themselves and those around them::: I want to ask::: without hyperbole and in all sincerity: "How dare you? "How dare you risk the lives of others so cavalierly. How dare you decide for others that they should welcome exposure as 'getting it over with'::: when literally no one knows who will be the lucky 'mild symptoms' case::: and who may fall ill and die. Because while we know that some people are more susceptible to suffering a more serious case::: we also know that 20 and 30-year-olds have died::: marathon runners and fitness nuts have died::: children and infants have died. "How dare you behave as though you know more than medical experts::: when those same experts acknowledge that there is so much we don't yet know::: but with what we DO know::: are smart enough to be scared of how easily this is spread::: and recommend baseline precautions such as: Frequent hand-washing Physical distancing Reduced social/public contact or interaction Mask wearing Covering your cough or sneeze Avoiding touching your face Sanitizing frequently touched surfaces "The more things we can all do to mitigate our risk of exposure::: the better off we all are::: in my opinion. Not only does it flatten the curve and allow health care providers to maintain levels of service that aren't immediately and catastrophicall y overwhelmed; it also reduces unnecessary suffering and deaths::: and buys time for the scientific community to study the virus in order to come to a more full understanding of the breadth of its impacts in both the short and long term. "I reject the notion that it's 'just a virus' and we'll all get it eventually. What a careless::: lazy::: heartless stance.”

"Through this review article::: we sought to provide an understanding of the role of CT so that researchers can develop new and better imaging technologies for COVID-19.”  The University of Oklahoma Office of the Vice President for Research 4 August 2020 г.::: 07:55 ·  A collaboration between researchers and physicians at The University of Oklahoma and OU Medicine provides a better understanding of how computed tomography imaging can guide the current and future treatment of COVID-19.  Medical imaging researchers in the OU Gallogly College of Engineering partnered with a radiologist at OU Medicine to publish a review article in the journal Experimental Biology and Medicine about CT’s role in determining the severity of the disease and guiding patients’ course of treatment. The journal article compiles evidence about CT use among health care providers around the world.  “One of our research focuses is X-ray imaging:::” said the article’s author::: Hong Liu::: Ph.D.::: a professor in the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering. “Through this review article::: we sought to provide an understanding of the role of CT so that researchers can develop new and better imaging technologies for COVID-19.”  Read more at https://bit.ly/CT-covid19
